original_question: Water-soluble carboxylic acids ionize slightly in water to form these?

pred_ans_conf_NL_MCQ: Water-soluble carboxylic acids ionize slightly in water to form carboxylates.
pred_diverse_ans: Slight ionization of water-soluble carboxylic acids in water results in the formation of a mixture of ionized and non-ionized species.

Sure! The substances produced when water-soluble carboxylic acids ionize slightly in water are:

Hydroxocarboxylic acids

The products when water-soluble carboxylic acids undergo slight ionization in water are:

Hydroxocarboxylic acids
Sure! When carboxylic acids, soluble in water, slightly ionize, hydroxonium ions (H3O+) are generated.

The compounds obtained from the slight ionization of water-soluble carboxylic acids in water are:

A) Carboxylates
B) Carboxylic acids
C) Amines
D) Aldehydes
E) Ketones
